title: Awesome week for AI in Business...
headline: üåü Microsoft‚Äôs AI-Powered Canva-Like Designer App Launches on iOS and Android Microsoft has announced that its AI-powered Designer app, akin to Canva, is now available to all users on iOS and Android. This follows its initial preview phase.
post_text: üåü Microsoft‚Äôs AI-Powered Canva-Like Designer App Launches on iOS and Android Microsoft has announced that its AI-powered Designer app, akin to Canva, is now available to all users on iOS and Android. This follows its initial preview phase. The app allows users to generate images and designs using text prompts, making it easy to create items such as stickers, greeting cards, invitations, collages, and more. Key Features: Wide Accessibility: Designer is now available in more than 80 languages on the web, as a free mobile app, and as a Windows app. Creative Templates: The app includes "prompt templates" to help kickstart the creative process. These templates come with styles and descriptions that users can customize and share. Versatile Creation Tools: Users can create emojis, clip art, wallpapers, monograms, avatars, and more using text prompts. AI Image Editing: The designer allows users to upload photos, such as selfies, and apply various styles or add details to transform them. Upcoming Features: A "replace background" feature will soon allow users to change image backgrounds using text prompts. New Designer App Features: Prompt Templates: New prompt templates help users jumpstart the creative process. These templates are pre-populated with ideas, styles, and descriptions that can be customized and shared. Custom Stickers and More: Users can create custom stickers, emojis, clip art, wallpapers, monograms, avatars, and more by describing what they want. Greeting Cards and Invitations: Create custom cards and invitations by describing what you want to convey. Restyle Image: You can transform any photo into a work of art by uploading it, choosing from a set of styles, and adding extra details. Frame Images and Collages: Upload photos, add descriptions, or choose from styles to create custom image frames and collages . Integration with Other Microsoft Services: Copilot Integration: The Designer service will be integrated into apps like Word and PowerPoint through Copilot. Copilot Pro subscribers can create images and designs within their workflow. For example, users can create banners for their documents in Word based on the document's content. Windows 11 Integration: Microsoft Photos on Windows 11 receives a deeper integration with Designer. Users can now edit photos using AI directly within the Photos app, enabling features like object erasure, background removal, and auto-cropping. Boosts for Faster Creation: The designer has 15 free daily boosts for creating or editing AI-powered images and designs faster. Users can upgrade to a Copilot Pro subscription to receive 100 daily boosts. Responsible AI Use Microsoft is committed to building tools that harness the potential of generative AI while providing a safe experience. Measures include guardrails, threat monitoring, abuse detection, and provenance technology to ensure responsible AI use. With these features, Microsoft Designer aims to simplify and enhance the design process for users, offering a powerful tool for easily creating and editing visuals. This new accessibility on mobile platforms and the additional integrations with other Microsoft services make Designer a versatile and valuable app for personal and professional use. üí¨ OpenAI Unveils GPT-4o Mini: A Smaller, Cheaper AI Model OpenAI has announced the release of GPT-4o mini, its latest small AI model, designed to be more cost-effective and faster than the current leading AI models. This new model is available for developers and users through the ChatGPT web and mobile app, with enterprise access coming next week. Key Features of GPT-4o Mini: Cost Efficiency : The GPT-4o mini is significantly more affordable than its predecessors, with a more than 60% cost reduction compared to the GPT-3.5 Turbo. Performance : It outperforms other small AI models, such as Gemini 1.5 Flash and Claude 3 Haiku, in reasoning tasks involving text and vision. Speed : With a median output speed of 202 tokens per second, it is more than twice as fast as GPT-4o and GPT-3.5 Turbo. Context Window : Supports up to 128,000 tokens, roughly the length of a book, making it ideal for extensive tasks. Text and Vision API Support : Currently supports text and vision, with plans to include video and audio capabilities in the future. Chart comparing small AI models from Artificial Analysis. Price here is a combination of input and output tokens. Credits: Artificial Analysis Additional Information: Availability and Pricing: GPT-4o mini is now available in the Assistants API, Chat Completions API, and Batch API. Pricing is set at 15 cents per 1M input tokens and 60 cents per 1M output tokens. Fine-tuning options will be available soon. In ChatGPT, Free, Plus, and Team users can access GPT-4o mini starting today, replacing GPT-3.5. Enterprise users will have access starting next week. Enterprise Tools : OpenAI has also introduced new tools for enterprise customers, including the Enterprise Compliance API to help businesses comply with logging and audit requirements, as well as enhanced admin controls for workspace GPTs. Olivier Godement, OpenAI‚Äôs head of Product API, stated, "For every corner of the world to be empowered by AI, we need to make the models much more affordable. GPT-4o mini is a significant step forward in that direction." Future Prospects OpenAI continues to reduce costs while enhancing AI capabilities. GPT-4o mini represents a significant step towards integrating AI into everyday applications, making it more accessible and practical for many uses. OpenAI's GPT-4o mini offers a compelling option for developers and enterprises looking for a fast, cost-efficient, and powerful AI model. With its robust features and affordable pricing, it is poised to make AI more accessible and practical for various applications. üé• Over 100K YouTube Videos Scraped to Train AI for Apple, Nvidia What do MrBeast, John Oliver, and The Wall Street Journal share? Their YouTube video transcripts have been scraped to train AI models used by companies like Apple, Nvidia, Anthropic, and Salesforce. An investigation by Wired and Proof News revealed that over 173,000 YouTube videos from more than 48,000 channels were included in a dataset called "YouTube Subtitles." Key Findings Massive Dataset : The "YouTube Subtitles" dataset contains transcripts from 173,536 YouTube videos across a diverse range of channels, including popular creators like Marques Brownlee and PewDiePie and educational content from Khan Academy, MIT, and Harvard. Unauthorized Use : The scraping of these transcripts was done without the creators' consent and against YouTube's terms of service, which prohibit the use of automated scrapers and the external use of uploaded videos. Content Concerns: The dataset includes not only reputable sources but also controversial and harmful content, such as "flat-Earth" conspiracy theories, profanity, and racial and gender slurs. Industry Impact Silicon Valley AI giants, including Apple and Nvidia, have used these scraped transcripts to train their generative AI models. Apple clarified that its OpenELM model, trained on this data, was used for research purposes and not for powering any AI or machine learning features. YouTube creators expressed their frustration over their content being used without permission. This unauthorized use also brings up potential legal issues, given that much of this data is under copyright. The AI industry has faced multiple copyright infringement lawsuits, including from major organizations like the New York Times and the Center for Investigative Reporting. Broader Implications The need for vast amounts of data to train AI models has led to these controversial practices. The New York Times reported that OpenAI also transcribed and used YouTube videos without consent for training GPT-4. AI companies may face a future where data becomes scarce, further complicating ethical and legal standards for data usage. Concerns Over Harmful Content The inclusion of unreliable and harmful content in AI training datasets is alarming. For instance, the LAION5-B dataset, used by the text-to-image generation model Stable Diffusion, contained Child Sexual Abuse Material (CSAM) and other problematic content, highlighting the risks of using unvetted data for AI training. Outcome Scraping YouTube video transcripts for AI training without consent raises significant ethical and legal concerns. As AI technology continues to evolve, companies must establish transparent and responsible data practices to protect creators and ensure the ethical use of content. üé®From Innovation to Imitation: Study Examines AI‚Äôs Role in Creativity Artificial intelligence (AI) has long been touted as a game-changer for the creative industries, influencing music, movies, books, and overall content creation. The promise of AI is not just to enhance but to transform these fields fundamentally. However, a recent study published in Science Advances warns that the widespread adoption of AI in storytelling could lead to a homogenization of creative outputs. The fear is that future books and movies may become monotonous and less diverse, with creative works starting to feel the same. The AI Creativity Experiment Researchers conducted an experiment to explore how generative AI might assist human creativity. Around 300 volunteers, not professional writers, participated as ‚Äúwriters.‚Äù Their creative potential was assessed using a standard psychological test requiring them to list 10 drastically different words. Experiment Setup: Themes: Ocean adventure, jungle expedition, or journey to another planet. Groups: Participants then wrote eight-sentence stories on their assigned themes. They evaluated their own creativity based on novelty, enjoyment, and the potential for the story to be developed into a published book. Additionally, 600 external reviewers assessed the stories using the same criteria. Individual Benefits: Collective Drawbacks: The study highlights a significant social dilemma: Pros: Cons: Researchers suggest a balanced approach: identify where AI tools can be best utilized while ensuring the unique creative voice remains intact. This balance can help maximize the benefits of AI without sacrificing the diversity and novelty of creative content. ü§ñAI Meets Excel: How Microsoft‚Äôs SpreadsheetLLM Is set to Change the Game Microsoft‚Äôs team of programmers and AI specialists has unveiled SpreadsheetLLM, an innovative tool that integrates large language model (LLM) capabilities with spreadsheets. Detailed in a study posted on the arXiv preprint server, the team also introduced SheetCompressor, an encoding framework designed to compress spreadsheets effectively for LLM use. While LLMs like ChatGPT have become household names, their limitations are increasingly evident, especially when it comes to understanding spreadsheets. Due to their complex structure, spreadsheets remain challenging for LLMs, hindering their potential as business tools. The Breakthrough: SheetCompressor In this study, Microsoft‚Äôs team developed a tool to reorganize spreadsheets into a format that LLMs can efficiently process. The cornerstone of this tool is SheetCompressor, a programming framework that enhances AI data management and analysis capabilities within spreadsheets. Key Functions of SheetCompressor: Compression: The team added anchors throughout the spreadsheet to help the LLM understand its structure and purpose. Rows and columns were then replaced with a simplified skeleton table. Translation: Modules were employed to eliminate empty cells or repeating values, streamlining the data. A lossless inverted index translation in JSON format facilitated data format aggregation. Data Format Aggregation: Additional modules addressed unique scenarios, such as adjacent cells with similar numerical formats. SpreadsheetLLM opens up new possibilities for LLM technology in handling spreadsheets. The tool can: Automate data entry Enhance data analysis Present complex information accessibly This innovation promises to make spreadsheets and their data more accessible and useful, essentially rewriting the way businesses and individuals manage and interpret data. Microsoft‚Äôs research team believes that SpreadsheetLLM will transform the utility of spreadsheets, making them indispensable tools for data-driven decision-making across various fields. This development heralds a new era of AI-powered efficiency in managing and interpreting spreadsheet data. üåêGemini 1.5 Pro Navigates The World In A Robot‚Äôs Body Google DeepMind's new research with Gemini 1.5 Pro enhances robot navigation by enabling them to understand and traverse complex environments using human instructions. The system processes various inputs, creating a topological graph from tour video frames to navigate without a map, achieving a 90% success rate in over 50 real-world interactions with employees. Details: DeepMind's "Mobility VLA" uses Gemini's 1M token context and map-like space representations for robust navigation. Robots receive a video tour of an environment, with key locations highlighted verbally, constructing a graph of the space from video frames. They respond to multimodal instructions, including map sketches, audio requests, and visual cues like a box of toys. Natural language commands, such as "take me somewhere to draw things," are also processed, guiding users to appropriate locations. The system, using "Multimodal Instruction Navigation with demonstration Tours (MINT)," familiarizes robots with spaces by walking them around and pointing out landmarks. Giving robots the ability to process complex multimodal inputs and understand extensive context opens up revolutionary possibilities. By seeing, hearing, thinking, and acting based on human instructions, this tech could transform robot assistants into highly interactive and perceptive helpers. üñ•Ô∏è Google Rolls Out Gemini AI-Powered Video and Presentation Tool Google has introduced Google Vids, an AI-powered video generation tool for presentations, integrated into the Workspace suite. Vids helps users create high-quality video presentations using Gemini AI, enhancing creativity and efficiency within Workspace by integrating docs, slides, voiceovers, and videos into a timeline to create presentations. Details: Uses Gemini AI for timeline creation, requiring user inputs rather than generating videos from prompts Allows starting with a textual prompt or choosing from various templates to generate a storyboard with titles for each section Supports adding Google Docs, Slides, videos, and audio recordings for more context Enables editing the storyboard by changing titles, reordering sections, and adding or deleting tiles Designs videos with stock videos, images, text, background music, and a generated script after picking a style Offers further edits, such as adding voice-over Currently available in Workspace Labs preview, with Workspace admins able to opt-in users to try out the AI-powered video maker. By leveraging user inputs and AI assistance, Google Vids allows for a higher degree of customization and creativity, ensuring presentations are both professional and personalized. The tool's ability to handle multiple formats and extensive editing options means users can produce polished videos without leaving the Workspace environment.

These updates suggest a significant expansion in ChatGPT's capabilities and integration with business environments, reflecting OpenAI's push to make their AI tools more versatile and enterprise-friendly. Earlier yesterday, Elon Musk's ùòÖùóîùóú rolled out a new AI chatbot named ùóöùóøùóºùó∏, positioning itself as a direct competitor to ChatGPT and probably overshadowing the Chatgpt's Dev Day announcement! üí•The upcoming event equips attendees with strategies for safe and ethical AI use, addressing governance, bias reduction, data privacy, risk management, and cybersecurity. It's a vital forum for learning about responsible AI deployment in an age of increasing scrutiny and potential regulation. üëâ Download the complimentary copy of the agenda for more information. Elon Musk's ùòÖùóîùóú has rolled out a new AI chatbot named ùóöùóøùóºùó∏, positioning itself as a direct competitor to Elon Musk's ùòÖùóîùóú has rolled out a new AI chatbot named ùóöùóøùóºùó∏ Here is what you should know about Grok: ‚úîÔ∏è What sets Grok apart is its real-time access to updated information, distinguishing it from other AI tools that rely on static knowledge. ‚úîÔ∏è Musk's reveal suggests Grok not only taps into live data but does so with a hint of humor and sarcasm, potentially reflecting Musk‚Äôs own personality. ‚úîÔ∏è It's designed to navigate complex and sensitive queries with a mix of wit and discretion, steering clear of promoting anything illicit. ‚úîÔ∏è For those interested in accessing Grok, it will be available to X Premium subscribers once it moves beyond its beta phase. Musk‚Äôs response to a request for access, "Ask, and you shall receive," hints at an inclusive approach for enthusiasts keen to try out the new AI. ‚úîÔ∏è Grok‚Äôs real-time information retrieval as a substantial advantage, especially for those seeking the latest news. The addition of humor is also seen as a strategic move, aligning with what Musk previously termed 'WokeGPT.' ‚úîÔ∏è A version of Grok is even expected to be integrated into Tesla's local computing systems, enhancing the vehicle's interactive features. ‚úîÔ∏è Lastly, even verified account holders on X will need to upgrade to the new Premium Plus plan to access Grok. Despite the extra cost, for tech and AI enthusiasts, this could be a worthwhile investment for cutting-edge interaction with AI. As developments unfold, it's clear that Grok is more than just another AI chatbot; it's an evolving platform that could redefine user interaction with real-time data and AI. üöÄHere is a not-to-be-missed webinar that‚Äôs all about scoring big with your LLM results using some slick tools. Totally blown away here. ü§© Runway rolled out this whopper of an update for their Text-to-Video and Image-to-Video.üöÄ üé§Join me as we explore how Generative AI is not just changing the game but revolutionizing the entire playing field of customer experience, featuring the esteemed Andy Traba, VP of Product Marketing at NICE . üëâJoin here UC Berkeley and Google researchers demonstrate a new method for generative AI that could replace diffusion models. Generative AI models like GANs and diffusion models create images by transforming inputs (like noise or corrupted images) into natural images. UC Berkeley and Google researchers have introduced "Idempotent Generative Networks" (IGNs), which aim to generate images from any input in ideally one step. IGNs act as a "global projector" to align any input with the target image distribution, not confined to particular inputs. This concept is inspired by a scene from the sitcom Seinfeld, related to idempotent operators. title: What to Expect in 2023 in AI by Stanford, Mckinsey, Forbes; Where is generative AI headed in 2023;
headline: Top Industries that are expected to leverage AI even more in 2023: Increased adoption of AI in healthcare: AI has the potential to revolutionize the healthcare industry by automating tasks, improving diagnosis accuracy, and enabling personalized medicine. In 2023, we can expect to see AI being used
post_text: Top Industries that are expected to leverage AI even more in 2023: Increased adoption of AI in healthcare: AI has the potential to revolutionize the healthcare industry by automating tasks, improving diagnosis accuracy, and enabling personalized medicine. In 2023, we can expect to see AI being used more widely in healthcare for tasks such as analyzing medical images, predicting patient outcomes, and identifying potential epidemics. Greater use of AI in customer service: AI-powered chatbots and virtual assistants are already being used by many companies to handle customer inquiries and complaints. In 2023, we can expect to see these technologies become even more sophisticated and widespread, allowing companies to provide 24/7 customer support while improving customer satisfaction. Development of AI-powered home automation: AI is already being used in smart home devices such as thermostats and security cameras, but in 2023 we can expect to see the development of even more advanced AI-powered home automation systems. These systems may be able to learn and adapt to a homeowner's preferences and habits, making it easier to control and manage the various devices in a home. Expanded use of AI in transportation: AI is already being used in self-driving cars and trucks, and in 2023 we can expect to see the development of even more advanced AI-powered transportation systems. This may include the use of AI to optimize traffic flow in cities, reduce accidents and congestion, and improve the efficiency of public transportation. Greater integration of AI in education: AI has the potential to transform education by providing personalized learning experiences and adapting to a student's individual needs. In 2023, we can expect to see AI being used more widely in education for tasks such as grading assignments, providing personalized learning recommendations, and helping students learn more efficiently. top_visible_comments.comment: I think that higher education has needed a facelift for a long time when it comes to evaluating whether students are truly learning or not. One of the considerations in my mind is what constitutes preparation for the real world. Surely this is a consideration when we talk about institutions "educating" students. We train students and we perceive that students are singularly successful if they get the answers "right" on their own, and if they can successfully parrot back accepted canon with all the annotations/references done in perfect format. I think this brand of AI is forcing us to reevaluate what that concept of education means. Let's be real about what rewording/rephrasing is today in classrooms where students aren't cheating, or specifically when the AI isn't doing that for students. Does the student's ability to reword/rephrase mean the net output is better, or proves they've learned the material? Maybe we should have students spend less time with reiterative paper writing and more time with collaborative learning, which is how things will really play out during the lifetime of their careers. Maybe more group projects with more practical outcomes are worth considering.

The advancements in AI are transforming the way we live and work. While there are many benefits to using AI, there are also concerns about its impact on society. One of the main concerns is the potential loss of jobs due to automation. However, AI can also create new jobs and opportunities. For example, AI can be used to develop new products and services, improve healthcare, and enhance education. Another concern is the ethical implications of AI. As AI becomes more advanced, it is important to ensure that it is used ethically and responsibly. This includes ensuring that AI is not used to discriminate against certain groups of people and that it is transparent and accountable.

post_text: The whole internet is blown up by ChatGPT, but what is it? ChatGPT is a powerful artificial intelligence tool that can generate human-like text. It uses state-of-the-art natural language processing (NLP) technology to understand and respond to human input. With ChatGPT, you can create engaging and realistic conversations with chatbots and other conversational systems. This opens up exciting possibilities for personalized and dynamic interactions with your audience. ChatGPT is open-source, so anyone can use and customize it to fit their needs. It can be used in a variety of applications, from customer service and e-commerce to entertainment and education. ChatGPT is constantly learning and improving, making it a valuable resource for anyone working with NLP and AI. Its ability to understand and generate human-like text makes it a valuable tool for anyone looking to add a personal touch to their chatbots and conversational systems. title: Is current social media a risk to humanity?
headline: I don‚Äôt think that there is any debate that we are living in a remarkably transformative time. Technology is advancing at a pace in which we are distinctly unfamiliar and while the positive impacts of change are generally understood, the vulnerability of moving so quickly is that we fail to fully un
post_text: I don‚Äôt think that there is any debate that we are living in a remarkably transformative time. Technology is advancing at a pace in which we are distinctly unfamiliar and while the positive impacts of change are generally understood, the vulnerability of moving so quickly is that we fail to fully understand the negative consequences of such a revolution. I think that is the case with social media where privacy breaches can occur, a reduction in real human connection is inevitable, mental health can take a thrashing (particularly in children), false information can be proliferated in the blink of an eye, and addiction can develop in much the same way it does for an alcohol abuser or a drug addict. While social media has clear benefits (knowledge sharing, access to information, connectivity, etc.), it likewise has faults. But what we really need to consider is if today, we are purposely designing systems with these known faults built-in because it happens to be more profitable for the big tech companies developing the platforms. On July 28, 2017, former Google employee, Tristan Harris, gave a Ted Talk titled ‚Äú How a Handful of Tech Companies Control Billions of Minds Every Day .‚Äù His aim in going public with his concerns was surely, at least in part, to make users of smart devices aware of the ways in which their technology (including social media) is continually and purposely designed to make these devices more addictive. In his Ted Talk, Harris casually and rather frighteningly, explains that these technology companies routinely and ‚Äú‚Ä¶ precisely target a lie directly to the people who are most susceptible . And because this is profitable, it‚Äôs only going to get worse .‚Äù There is no more urgent problem that faces us today than this one, because the more time we spend scrolling through our social media feeds, the more likely we are to be sucked into the bottomless pits of our own virtual realities and encounter all of the other societal problems that social media tends to introduce. So, while big tech companies are purposely designing systems to keep us engaged for their own financial motives, the fact is that the longer we are online, the more likely we are to be exposed to the dark underbelly of the web. For instance, companies like Facebook benefit (i.e., profit) when there is outrage regarding a particular story on a newsfeed, because outrage generates an emotional reaction, and that is something you are more likely to share. It‚Äôs called ‚Äú negative bias ‚Äù and it‚Äôs one of the reasons your local news station is more likely to dedicate significantly more airtime covering a story about an impending storm than it will about a beautiful summer day. A 2019 research paper published by the Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences (PNAS), a peer reviewed journal of the National Academy of Sciences (NAS), suggested what we already were inclined to believe, that consumers around the world have stronger psychophysiological reactions to negative news when compared to positive news. Of course, the unfortunate consequence of this type of emotional reaction to this type of negativity, is that the underlying toxicity and hate spreads like wildfire in a virtual environment and the end result is a drastic, and perhaps permanent, increase in reciprocal divisiveness. Social media dependence is also becoming much more commonplace, so much so that the United States Addiction Center has added a ‚ÄúSocial Media Addition‚Äù treatment program to its offerings. The fact is that when you get those warm and fuzzy feelings from a lot of likes hitting your Instagram post, it‚Äôs the same portion of your brain being activated as that of a drug addict on a high. And the more dependent you become, the harder you will fall if, and when, your account is ever banned, restricted, or deleted. We must consider putting a level of control on our online activity, either through individual diligence, algorithmic constraints or, if necessary, administrative regulations. The addiction component has a peripheral consequence in that many young people who are following the latest social media influencers get a small glimpse of what it would be like to generate enormous amounts of wealth while snapping selfies of yourself traveling around the world in Ferraris and yachts. The problem is that the actuality of that happening is like winning the lottery, your chances are mighty, mighty slim. But that doesn‚Äôt preclude the kids from trying, and the end result is that screen time swells as aspiring influencers strain to develop a devoted and sizeable following. And when that doesn‚Äôt happen (and statistically speaking it will not), the negative aspects of the failed attempt weigh extremely heavy on the impressionable mind of a young kid. According to the Brookings Institution , a nonpartisan and nonprofit public policy organization based in Washington, DC, ‚Äú while computer programmers may not create algorithms that start out being discriminatory, the collection and curation of social preferences eventually can become adaptive algorithms that embrace societal biases. If we accept that the implicit bias of developers could unintentionally lead their algorithms to be discriminatory, then, with the same token, we should also expect the biases of such programmers to lead to discriminatory algorithms that favor their ideology .‚Äù In other words, these technologies are designed to select only the most engaging and relevant content for each individual user and, in the process, deliberately ignore any alternative philosophies, thereby making the reader more vulnerable to manipulation. Effectively, these big tech giants have, for years, been deliberately and knowingly brainwashing readers to a single point of view, creating a generation‚Äôs worth of predisposed pseudo-intellectuals who feign insight by reiterating what has been encoded into their persuaded minds. It is outrageous to the point of criminality. These (very powerful) companies have been effectively operating exactly as tyrannical regimes, shadow banning those who oppose their views, suspending those who question their methods and eliminating those who demand accountability. Social media platforms are rapidly becoming the primary source of news information in the United States and across the world. Yet these platforms are not only manipulating the type of news that you are exposed to but allowing you to absorb content that is intentionally published with dubious accuracy. And no one is holding them accountable. Here's the thing. We all know that these big tech giants are in it for the money. And, in a way, that is capitalistically understandable. But if we want to keep this thing from flying off the rails, we really need to start considering the question of regulating social-media platforms and other internet services. These companies should not have stayed under the radar for this long, transparency, fairness and privacy are some of the major topics to consider regarding these platforms.

People who become addicted to social media and fail to adjust to reality (including real human relationships) will eventually die out. Primitive societies, if we allow them to continue to exist, will eventually take over humanity. We must remember that every technological advancement is a two-edged sword. The way that technology is used can be more important than the technology itself. I am not a Luddite (having earned three degrees in EE from MIT before my 22nd birthday), but I am a realist.

I have been really interested in health... books that you can find in the San Francisco Public Library on health such as Metabolical. (Dewey # 616). post_text: ChatGPT is still hot, but why? ChatGPT is a powerful artificial intelligence tool that can generate human-like text. It uses state-of-the-art natural language processing (NLP) technology to understand and respond to human input. How does it work? ChatGPT is a fine-tuned version of GPT-3.5, an update that the company had not previously announced. GPT-3's technology is simple. It takes your requests, questions, or prompts and quickly answers them. As you would imagine, the technology to do this is a lot more complicated than it sounds. He helped popularize backpropagation and invented the Boltzmann machine. Recently, he published a new paper describing a new algorithm called The Forward-Forward Algorithm (FF) . title: Top Machine Learning / Deep Learning Courses on Youtube
headline: Machine Learning Course (Caltech) By Yaser Abu-Mostafa This is an introductory course on machine learning that covers basic theory, algorithms, and applications. Machine learning (ML) enables computational systems to adaptively improve their performance with experience accumulated from the observed
post_text: Machine Learning Course (Caltech) By Yaser Abu-Mostafa This is an introductory course on machine learning that covers basic theory, algorithms, and applications. Machine learning (ML) enables computational systems to adaptively improve their performance with experience accumulated from the observed data. ML techniques are widely applied in engineering, science, finance, and commerce to build systems for which we do not have full mathematical specifications (and that covers a lot of systems). The course balances theory and practice and covers the mathematical as well as the heuristic aspects. Making Friends with Machine Learning By Cassie Kozyrkov The course is designed to give you the tools you need for effective participation in machine learning to solve business problems and for being a good citizen in an increasingly AI-fueled world. MFML is perfect for all humans; it focuses on conceptual understanding (rather than the mathematical and programming details) and guides you through the ideas that form the basis of successful approaches to machine learning. Machine Learning (Stanford) By Andrew Ng This course provides a broad introduction to machine learning and statistical pattern recognition. Topics include supervised learning (generative/discriminative learning, parametric/non-parametric learning, neural networks, support vector machines); unsupervised learning (clustering, dimensionality reduction, kernel methods); learning theory (bias/variance tradeoffs, practical advice); reinforcement learning and adaptive control. The course will also discuss recent applications of machine learning, such as robotic control, data mining, autonomous navigation, bioinformatics, speech recognition, and text and web data processing. Machine Learning for Intelligent Systems (CORNELL) By Kilian Weinberger The goal of this course is to give an introduction to the field of machine learning. The course will teach you basic skills to decide which learning algorithm to use for what problem, code up your own learning algorithm and evaluate and debug it. Prerequisites: CSE 241 and sufficient mathematical maturity (Matrix Algebra, probability theory/statistics, multivariate calculus). Applied Machine Learning (CORNELL) By Volodymyr Kuleshov Starting from the very basics, we cover all of the most important ML algorithms and how to apply them in practice. The slides are also Jupyter notebooks with programmatically generated figures. Readers can tweak parameters and regenerate the figures themselves. Also, whenever we introduce an important mathematical formula, we implement it in NumPy. This helps establish connections between the math and how to apply it in code. Another idea we tried was to include 3 full lectures on how to apply ML in practice in a principled way. This includes topics such as how to prioritize model improvements, diagnose overfitting, perform error analysis, visualize loss curves, etc. Machine Learning with Graphs (Stanford) By Jure Leskovec This course covers important research on the structure and analysis of such large social and information networks and on models and algorithms that abstract their basic properties. Students will explore how to practically analyze large-scale network data and how to reason about it through models for network structure and evolution. Probabilistic Machine Learning (T√ºbingen) By Philipp Hennig The course covers the probabilistic ("Bayesian") paradigm for machine learning, and occasionally draws direct connections to statistical (e.g. Lecture 10) and deep learning (e.g. Lecture 8). The course is aimed at master's students in computer science and related fields. Introduction to Deep Learning (MIT) By Alexander Amini & Ava Soleimany Introductory course on deep learning methods with applications to computer vision, natural language processing, biology, and more! Students will gain foundational knowledge of deep learning algorithms and get practical experience in building neural networks in TensorFlow. Deep Unsupervised Learning (UC Berkeley) By Pieter Abbeel, Peter Chen, Jonathan Ho, Aravind Srinivas This course will cover two areas of deep learning in which labeled data is not required: Deep Generative Models and Self-supervised Learning. Recent advances in generative models have made it possible to realistically model high-dimensional raw data such as natural images, audio waveforms, and text corpora. Strides in self-supervised learning have started to close the gap between supervised representation learning and unsupervised representation learning in terms of fine-tuning to unseen tasks. This course will cover the theoretical foundations of these topics as well as their newly enabled applications. Deep Learning (Stanford) By Andrew Ng You will learn about Convolutional networks, RNNs, LSTM, Adam, Dropout, BatchNorm, Xavier/He initialization, and more. You will work on case studies from healthcare, autonomous driving, sign language reading, music generation, and natural language processing. You will master not only the theory but also see how it is applied in the industry. You will practice all these ideas in Python and in TensorFlow, which we will teach. Practical Deep Learning for Coders (Fastai) By Sylvain Gugger and Jeremy Howard How to train models that achieve state-of-the-art results. How to turn your models into web applications, and deploy them. Why and how deep learning models work, and how to use that knowledge to improve the accuracy, speed, and reliability of your models. The latest deep learning techniques that really matter in practice. How to implement stochastic gradient descent and a complete training loop from scratch. How to think about the ethical implications of your work, to help ensure that you're making the world a better place and that your work isn't misused for harm. Deep Learning (UC Berkeley) By Sergey Levine This is an introductory deep learning course covering a broad range of deep learning topics (basic machine learning, convolutional neural networks, recurrent neural networks, transformers, NLP, reinforcement learning, generative models & GANs. Deep Learning (NYU) By Yann LeCun & Alfredo Canziani This course concerns the latest techniques in deep learning and representation learning, focusing on supervised and unsupervised deep learning, embedding methods, metric learning, convolutional and recurrent nets, with applications to computer vision, natural language understanding, and speech recognition. Deep Learning Lecture Series (DeepMind x UCL) By multiple lecturers In this lecture series, leading research scientists from the leading AI research lab, DeepMind, deliver 12 lectures on an exciting selection of topics in Deep Learning, ranging from the fundamentals of training neural networks via advanced ideas around memory, attention, and generative modeling to the important topic of responsible innovation. Full Stack Deep Learning (UC Berkeley) By Sergey Karayev, Pieter Abbeel & Josh Tobin This course teaches full-stack production deep learning: Formulating the problem and estimating project cost. Finding, cleaning, labeling, and augmenting data. Picking the right framework and computing infrastructure. Troubleshooting training and ensuring reproducibility. Deploying the model at scale.

headline: Survivorship bias: This might be Old but definitely inspiring During World War II, fighter planes would come back from battle with bullet holes. The Allies found the areas that were most commonly hit by enemy fire.
post_text: Survivorship bias: This might be Old but definitely inspiring During World War II, fighter planes would come back from battle with bullet holes. The Allies found the areas that were most commonly hit by enemy fire. They sought to strengthen the most commonly damaged parts of the planes to reduce the number that was shot down. A mathematician, Abraham Wald, pointed out that perhaps there was another way to look at the data. Perhaps the reason certain areas of the planes weren't covered in bullet holes was that planes that were shot in those areas did not return. This insight led to the armor being re-enforced on the parts of the plane where there were no bullet holes. The story behind the data is arguably more important than the data itself. Or more precisely, the reason behind why we are missing certain pieces of data may be more meaningful than the data we have. headline: If you‚Äôve been keeping up with the cryptocurrency world, you‚Äôve probably come across the term ‚ÄúNFT.‚Äù They are one-of-a-kind, non-interchangeable digital assets that also serve as valid proof of ownership on the blockchain.
post_text: If you‚Äôve been keeping up with the cryptocurrency world, you‚Äôve probably come across the term ‚ÄúNFT.‚Äù They are one-of-a-kind, non-interchangeable digital assets that also serve as valid proof of ownership on the blockchain. Recently, an AI Art Piece broke the record of the highest price on the NFT market. Even if you don't want to buy or make NFTs, it is still better to educate yourself about the technology. What the hell are NFTs? Read more about NFTs in my previous issue . When most people think of NFTs, they think it is only the profile pics, some [Adjectives][Animals], or pixilated images. This couldn't be further from the truth! They were supposed to be digital representations of art, they are indivisible and non-replicable, to which people can attach value. Good news! There is a growing movement to make NFTs usable in several different ways by adding utilities to create a different kind of value proposition, on top of their scarcity and collectability. Utility NFTs have valuations based on the access and opportunities they provide to the holders. They offer clearly defined intrinsic value in addition to the usual scarcity associated with NFTs. The main types of NFTs are: One of the more novel concepts is the NFT staking or farming. This refers to staking NFTs to a protocol to earn a yield. It gives NFTs passive yield-generating utility and can be thought of as decentralized finance meets NFTs. A common concept in this scenario is the staking portal where you can turn compatible NFTs into vaults from which you earn rewards. An example of a staking portal would be the Genesis Farm. Where users are allowed to stake free MEME tokens to farm limited edition NFTs which can then be sold on NFT marketplaces such as OpenSea or Rarible. The market will mature in the near future and more utilities will be integrated into NFTs, which is, unfortunately, following a hyped trend now. Always, think about utilities and the long-term games and never buy NFTs from anonymous creators with no LinkedIn Account. Here is a guide to identifying high potential projects: https://lnkd.in/gQdmNg2Y Disclaimer: This is not financial advice, always do your own research. I am not sure that the best use of NFT's is for art. The value of NFT's is in the secure tracking of millions or even better billions of transactions. An example of a good use of NFT's would be the tracking of all the transactions in shipping where the current paper trail is cumbersome and time consuming as well as inaccurate. NFT's could speed up the process and make it much more accurate. The underlying Blochian technology that makes NFT's safe becomes more secure and beneficial when the rate of transactions is high and the complex nature of transactions and tracking of ownership makes the idea of NFT's useful when applied to complex transactional problems. The publicity stunt of selling a horribly pixelated lion for a ridiculous amount was simply that a publicity stunt designed to popularize NFT's and it worked, but now we should be responsible and stop trying to chance instant fortunes but apply NFT's to applications that they will work best for,
A lot to learn. Thanks.

headline: Don't trade NFTs unless you read this! What is NFT? you can check these posts (1, 2, 3 ). What are the types of NFTs? No NFTs are not just animal jpegs! Are they Scam or Ponzi schemes? Some of them based on the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) definition are, but if you do your homework and
post_text: Don't trade NFTs unless you read this! What is NFT? you can check these posts ( 1 , 2 , 3 ). What are the types of NFTs? No NFTs are not just animal jpegs! Are they Scam or Ponzi schemes? Some of them based on the Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) definition are, but if you do your homework and avoid the red flags , the technology is an enabler for many great use cases. NFTs are new and unregulated, so there is more chance for people to misuse the hype. Especially, there has been a recent rise in fraudulent projects . OpenSea ( NFT Marketplace) reported that around 80 percent of the NFTs minted through its free creation tool had been identified as fraudulent, earmarked as either spam or scams. That's why many people believe that is all the same and overgeneralize the problem. The cartoon is attributed to 1889 and is entitled ‚ÄúThe Unrestrained Demon‚Äù, referring to the electricity itself. There was some truth to this: in the early days of electrification when the importance of grounding/bonding wasn't well understood (or followed when it was), people were getting shocked at random, horses getting shocked through their iron shoes.** Not all NFTs are scams and Fraudulent. I still believe they are all scams or I don't have the capacity to find the ones that are legit, should I still buy them? Absolutely not, stay away from NFTs and enjoy your life! If you are really in for the trouble then keep reading, as, with any financial decision , you should do a lot of research before getting started, not just on the project, but on the NFT industry as a whole. These are some tips: (This is not financial Advice make sure to do your own research) Look who is behind the project and what are the creators‚Äô backstories are good places to start. Never ever buy NFTs from unknown and anonymous creators. Having a LinkedIn account is a must unless you are into gambling! Don't buy NFTs that have no intrinsic value from a real-world utility or if it is too complex to understand. Only buy art NFTs if you are enjoying them yourself and not for the profit, because there is a high chance to lose money after the hype fades away. I made a poll a while ago and only 12% of voters (2700+) believe NFTs are bought for the art! But, it would be great to have a pleasant art piece on top of some utility. Finally, check if the majority of the community that supports the project are legit NFT collectors and not flippers. It is easy to get overwhelmed by the numbers but are they real? They can be bots and paid resources from low-wage countries that try to inflate the numbers by saying gm/gn a couple of times a day. As I mentioned before 90% of the current projects are going to fail soon, make sure you are not holding a bag full of them. What is the Metaverse? The latest Silicon Valley buzzword is a merger of core technologies advanced in the previous decade. It is a combination of the Internet Of Things, Artificial Intelligence, Blockchain, Augmented Reality, Virtual Reality, 5G & Moore‚Äôs Law. The metaverse isn‚Äôt just a buzzword, it is the inevitable evolution of the internet. It‚Äôs more than NFTs and VR goggles, it‚Äôs the shift in how we communicate using technology. The Internet Of Things aspect provides glasses, goggles, and bodysuits that receive real-time data and react accordingly. The blockchain provides NFTs that secure assets, smart contracts, and incentive models that create trustless reward mechanisms. Augmented Reality creates digital elements in the real world. Virtual reality is a 360-degree interactive environment. Artificial Intelligence allows features, assets, and environments to have logic that improves the experience of the metaverse over time. 5G allows for nearly instant communication and real-time feedback. Finally, Moore‚Äôs Law guarantees that technology will continue to get smaller and more powerful. What looks like a Janky headset today becomes ray ban sunglasses tomorrow and contact lenses the day after. The metaverse is the tech boom.

headline: Web 3.0 and NFTs are dominating the Fintech news these days, you all have heard about crazy amounts paid for art pieces that might not look so impressive from the technical perspective.
post_text: Web 3.0 and NFTs are dominating the Fintech news these days, you all have heard about crazy amounts paid for art pieces that might not look so impressive from the technical perspective. Also, many artists are using AI to generate some unique art pieces including AI-generated Voices , which makes it more interesting for me. The revolution is not limited to the art market. While NFT adoption in gaming has already reached a certain maturity, for example concerning the trade of in-game objects, different other industries, especially those involved with the production of digital content such as music or video, are experimenting with the technology. So what is NFT? Non-Fungible just means that you can‚Äôt interchange one asset from another. A token in the case of NFTs is just a certificate of authenticity that sits on a blockchain ‚Äî which makes the token verifiable and visible to everyone. Thus, an NFT is a unique digital asset in the forms of art, videos, audio, and any other form of digital creation. NFTs can be used for practical governance use cases like copyright and general storage of sensitive, social information that would otherwise be too prone to abuse in the hands of centralized authorities that increasingly demonstrate contempt for the public. Records such as voter tallies, census information, titles of ownership, and medical records may be able to find protection within an NFT framework that is publicly owned. The future of NFTs goes far beyond social status, memes or multimillion-dollar works of art turned profile pictures. This is just the beginning of a global revolution that started out disrupting banking and is now going to disrupt everything else. 98% of NFTs in 2022 will be a bad investment. It's only a matter of time before most of the NFT artworks will lose their allure to all but a small group of enthusiasts. NFTs are much more than profile pics, make sure to buy Utilities not the hype! This is not financial advice, always do your own research. While previous estimates from organizations like Goldman Sachs, McKinsey, and various universities indicated significant automation potential, the MIT study focused specifically on the economic feasibility of automating jobs requiring visual analysis. It found that the majority of these jobs are not yet economically beneficial to automate. The study calculated the costs of deploying and maintaining AI systems, revealing that only a small fraction of wages for vision tasks would justify automation. The researchers also considered more affordable, self-hosted AI systems but found that many jobs still wouldn't be cost-effective to automate. They emphasized that the transition to AI automation in certain tasks will take decades and acknowledged limitations such as not considering AI's role in augmenting human labor. The study also addressed potential bias concerns due to funding from the MIT-IBM Watson AI Lab. Finally, it advised policymakers to prepare for AI job automation and highlighted the need for AI developers to focus on reducing costs and expanding the scope of AI deployment. üß† Meta Released a Prompt Engineering cookbook It is an interactive guide covering prompt engineering and best practices for developers, researchers, and enthusiasts working with large language models. ‚úîSome of the ideas: Role Prompting: Assigning roles to the model can yield more consistent and contextually appropriate responses. Chain-of-Thought Prompting: Encouraging a step-by-step thought process in prompts significantly improves the model's ability to perform complex reasoning. Self-Consistency: The self-consistency method enhances accuracy by generating multiple responses and selecting the most frequent answer. Retrieval-Augmented Generation: This technique involves incorporating external facts into prompts to provide more accurate and factual information. More... Many thanks for the support! Stay tuned for more insights and updates from the world of technology!üôè

title: Web 3.0, AI+NFT, Data2Vec! AI wins Poker, Summarizes research papers, Scans Eyes and Detects Emotions
headline: Web3 is an umbrella term for ideas of eliminating the big middlemen on the internet. To better understand Web3, let‚Äôs go through Web1 and Web2 first and have a comparison of the features.
post_text: Web3 is an umbrella term for ideas of eliminating the big middlemen on the internet. To better understand Web3, let‚Äôs go through Web1 and Web2 first and have a comparison of the features. Web1: Read-Only The majority of users using the internet in the ‚Äò90s were consumers on static web pages and rarely produced content. People came onto the internet to consume read-only content. There were a few ‚Äúinternet companies‚Äù controlled content on the internet. Web2: Read-Write Web2 is what we mostly engage these days took over in the early 2000s. It made space for everyone to become a content creator and consumer simultaneously on social networks, i.e. Linkedin, Twitter, and Facebook, who can leverage or sell personal data to generate impressive amounts of revenue because centralized companies have ownership over user data and all user-generated content. Users can: Classify and sort information Create and develop APIs for interoperability across different software Create and share dynamic and responsive content with others Send and receive information from different sources Access content from mobile devices, multimedia consoles, televisions, and more Web3: Read-Write-Own The shift from Web2 to Web3 is largely due to infrastructure advancement and a mindset shift for developers as governance will be much more user-centered. With the removal of a middleman and data living on immutable infrastructure, there is no control over data and less risk of data loss. One of the most significant implications of decentralization and blockchain technology is in the area of data ownership and compensation. As we move toward Web 3.0 and the technologies that support it mature and become scalable, I believe the web will reflect its original intent. Non-fungible tokens ( NFTs ) will also play a huge role in reshaping the gaming industry by allowing players to become the immutable owners of the items they accrue. Some believe that starting with Web3 is by setting up your crypto wallet (i.e. MetaMask) connected to decentralized apps to interact and conduct transactions. Web 3.0 is a leap forward, it creates the infrastructure needed for humans and machines to interact, create, find, and share distributed data, make accurate predictions with artificial intelligence, and be empowered to control one‚Äôs identity through a web of trust, security, and privacy. [MIT] Meta‚Äôs new learning algorithm can teach AI to multi-task Data2vec uses two neural networks, a student and a teacher. First, the teacher network is trained on images, text, or speech in the usual way, learning an internal representation of this data that allows it to predict what it is seeing when shown new examples. When it is shown a photo of a dog, it recognizes it as a dog. [Verge] A NEW USE FOR AI: SUMMARIZING SCIENTIFIC RESEARCH FOR SEVEN-YEAR-OLDS: a project that leverages recent advances in AI language processing to simplify science. [VB] New startup shows how emotion-detecting AI is intrinsically problematic : [Facial expressions] in question are not ‚Äòfingerprints‚Äô or diagnostic displays that reliably and specifically signal particular emotional states regardless of context, person, and culture,‚Äù [ZDNet] Google rolls out Vertex AI Forecast for retailers: It is a tool for retailers to help generate more accurate demand forecasts. The tool is part of the managed Vertex AI platform that Google rolled out last year to help enterprises quickly deploy machine learning. [GEN] Using AI to Assess Eye Scans, Scientists Find ‚ÄúRetinal Age Gap‚Äù Predicts Mortality Risk An international team of scientists has found that the difference between the biological age of an individual‚Äôs retina and that person‚Äôs real, chronological age, is linked to their risk of death. [Eurekalert] Start of the European AI language model project Open GPT-X The OpenGPT-X project is starting with the goal of developing a large AI language model for Europe. Particular attention is being paid to data protection as well as European language diversity. [Wired] How to know when AI is the right solution: Business value, training data, and cultural readiness are essential for AI success. Without all three, traditional solutions are your best bet. [NY Times] How A.I. Conquered Poker: Good poker players have always known that they need to maintain a balance between bluffing and playing it straight. Now they can do so perfectly. [Fortune] Men are creating AI girlfriends, verbally abusing them, and bragging about it: The friendship app Replika was created to give users a virtual chatbot to socialize with. But how it‚Äôs now being used has taken a darker turn. [VB] 5 ways AI and ML will improve cybersecurity in 2022: Cyberattacks are happening faster, targeting multiple threat surfaces simultaneously using a broad range of techniques to evade detection and access valuable data. [The New Yorker] The Rise of A.I. Fighter Pilots : Artificial intelligence is being taught to fly warplanes. Can the technology be trusted? [IEEE] A First: AI System Named Inventor : A patent was granted that lists it as the creator of a food container {Ad} The Voiceverse is made by LOVO AI , the NFT holders get to use the AI model to create content using TTS and STS applications. They get to mint their own Voice NFTs, and mix and create new ones. Stake the NFT for a passive income. You can give it a try and join discord community with 25K users. [üöÄ] What AI cannot do? title: Which NFTs? Shapeshifting Robot, Building a Data Science Roadmap, AI reading lips, and new ConvNet 2022!
headline: You dont need to be a Crypto maximalist to understand the potential of an enaibler technology. I am not talking about JPGs and profile pictures here, it is much bigger than the current hype.
post_text: You dont need to be a Crypto maximalist to understand the potential of an enaibler technology. I am not talking about JPGs and profile pictures here, it is much bigger than the current hype. Before even starting, I need to say 90% of the current NFT projects will fail soon and will have no values in future. If you dont know what are NFTs, please check my post here . Having said that there is a future for NFTs that I totally recommend everyone to learn more about the ecosystem and usecases. This topic is not very trendy on Linkedin yet but I am going to start a series of educational posts called " 30 days of Web3.0 " to share may views and experiences about many related topics including NFTs. If you are still considering to enter this risky market, make sure to read the rest carefully. These are 4 factors that will help you make the right decision finding high potential projects: 1- The team behind the project: Even if you are just buying to flip it, make sure they are real people with some tracable background. Having a LinkedIn account is a bonus. Check their past experiences and relevance to the current project. Like any other businesses you need to look for a diverse skills including art, tech and business. 2- The community : Most of the projects have a discord space and social media accounts. Check their engagements to understand if the members are real or bots. Ideally, there is a couple of thousands active users on their discord channels talking about relevant topics. 3- The utility: If you are an art lover and collector, Skip this one! It is very important to get something more than just a pixelated ( or even a high res) animal image. When the hype goes away this will save the value of the asset. Some of the projects have a crazy roadmap but you need to check their team to ensure they can deliver it. Like any other businesses, there is always a chance to get fooled by another Theranos . 4- The artifact : Apart from some early examples, these days most NFTs need to have pleasing aethtetics. Art is subjective but at least it should feel good for you If not buying a purly Utility NFTs. It is always better to buy an NFT that has a known artist with a track of record on Linkedin/Instagram. After following all of these, still there is no guarantee the NFT that you bought would hold the value in the short/long term. So, make sure to use some assets that you can afford to lose. In near future, when the hype goes away and the technology matures to have more utility NFTs with a concrete offerings, there will be less risks/rewards. This is a poll I posted on Linked a couple of days ago, the results are really interesting. I you have not voted yet, you can find it here. **I am not a financial advisor and this is not financial advice. NFT space is risky now, do your own research and make decisions carefully** [LinkedIn Post] New shape-shifting micro robot swims through the body to deliver the cancer drug directly to the target. title: NFT 2.0! Top AI stories of 2021 and predictions for 2022. Human Brain Cells VS AI.
headline: If you‚Äôve been keeping up with the cryptocurrency world, you‚Äôve probably come across the term ‚ÄúNFT.‚Äù They are one-of-a-kind, non-interchangeable digital assets that also serve as valid proof of ownership on the blockchain.
post_text: If you‚Äôve been keeping up with the cryptocurrency world, you‚Äôve probably come across the term ‚ÄúNFT.‚Äù They are one-of-a-kind, non-interchangeable digital assets that also serve as valid proof of ownership on the blockchain. Recently, an AI Art Piece broke the record of the highest price on the NFT market. Read more about NFTs in my previous issue . When most people think of NFTs, they think it is only the profile pics, some [Adjectives][Animals], or pixilated images. This couldn't be further from the truth ! They were supposed to be digital representations of art, they are indivisible and non-replicable, to which people can attach value. Good news! There is a growing movement to make NFTs usable in several different ways by adding utilities to create a different kind of value proposition, on top of their scarcity and collectability. Utility NFTs have valuations based on the access and opportunities they provide to the holders. They offer clearly defined intrinsic value in addition to the usual scarcity associated with NFTs. It is still the early stages of utility NFTs but they are broadly classified into the following categories: Community NFTs Sports NFTs Gambling NFTs In-game NFTs Social NFTs One of the more novel concepts is the NFT staking or farming. This refers to staking NFTs to a protocol to earn a yield. It gives NFTs passive yield-generating utility and can be thought of as decentralized finance meets NFTs. A common concept in this scenario is the staking portal where you can turn compatible NFTs into vaults from which you earn rewards. An example of a staking portal would be the Genesis Farm. Where users are allowed to stake free MEME tokens to farm limited edition NFTs which can then be sold on NFT marketplaces such as OpenSea or Rarible. I have shared a poll on LinkedIn 3 days ago asking "Have you ever bought NFTs?". It received 7000+ responses and the result is very interesting, check it here . Disclaimer: I am not a financial advisor, I don't encourage or discourage anyone to buy/ flip NFTs, It is a financial decision that should be made with care. Web 3.0 is interesting from the technology perspective for me and I just shared some bite-size simple explanations here. MIT‚Äôs top research stories of 2021 , Forbes 10 AI Predictions For 2022 [TC] Global stakeholders should use AI to mitigate impact of heat islands in cities : A map, or a topographic view, allows climate teams in municipalities to get the land surface temperature of every 30-meter block on the ground. Also, there‚Äôs a Scenario Modeling View that enables them to generate scenarios of the future urban sprawl of cities by modifying features like building counts and height and other urban sprawl parameters. [TC] Dental AI tech company raised 42 million: Boston-based Overjet‚Äôs dental AI software supports dentists in understanding what the scans show with regard to disease identification and progression [MIT] Characters for good, created by artificial intelligence: Researchers encourage positive use cases of AI-generated characters for education and well-being. A team from a couple of universities have compiled an open-source, easy-to-use character generation pipeline that combines AI models for facial gestures, voice, and motion and can be used to create a variety of audio and video outputs. [Health it analytics] Using Artificial Intelligence to Identify Fractures on X-rays : This AI algorithm can quickly and automatically detect x-rays that are positive for fractures and flag those studies in the system so that radiologists can prioritize reading x-rays with positive fractures. [VB] NLP is the heart of the intelligent enterprise: Back-office functions ranging from software development and data analytics to systems management and risk assessment become far more efficient and effective when humans can simply speak their desires rather than type them in or click their way through endless menus. [HBR] 50 Global Hubs for Top AI Talent : Building ethical AI that works for everyone will require a diverse workforce that brings a broad range of perspectives. To achieve this, however, companies will need to look outside of the usual hubs, such as San Francisco. To aid in that effort, the authors have compiled the top 50 cities for AI talent and analyzed how diverse the population of developers is in each. [Gardian] Can AI really predict crime: The Los Angeles police department rolled out the first predictive policing programme of its kind in the US, allowing the LAPD to use historical data to predict with laser precision (hence the name) where future crimes might be committed and who might commit them. [HPC] How Financial Organizations Leverage AI To Deliver Smarter, More Secure Services: By leveraging data to drive deeper, more holistic insights, AI initiatives improve upon traditional approaches to new service development, risk management, payment fraud, automated claims handling and better customer experience. [OpenAI] Improving the factual accuracy : A fine-tuned GPT-3 to more accurately answer open-ended questions using a text-based web browser. Our prototype copies how humans research answers to questions online ‚Äì it submits search queries, follows links, and scrolls up and down web pages. [ZDNet] Eliminating artificial intelligence bias is everyone's job: A call for more awareness and training behind AI deployments. Not just for developers and data scientists, bur also product managers, executives, marketing managers, and merchandisers. [NewScientist]: Human brain cells in a dish learn to play Pong faster than an AI: Hundreds of thousands of brain cells in a dish are being taught to play Pong by responding to pulses of electricity ‚Äì and can improve their performance more quickly than an AI can. [üêî] Demonstration of Reinforcement Learning on a (DNNN) [üöÄ] All you need to know about transformers [üí•] AI in 2022: What decision you need to make in the new year [‚úî] Data storytelling is an art. [ü¶ä] Positive affirmations for a successful start to the new year! Merry Christmas and Happy new year! Hope you all have a great holdidays whereever you are. title: AI Weekly #4
headline: Last week, I got invited to emcee the AI Innovation Expo by Boab and moderate two-panel discussions about AI. First, there was a debate between Dr Catriona Wallace and Jeremy Howard on the topic of ‚ÄúIs the AI existential threat real?‚Äù Separate from the issues of bias that occur with machine learning
post_text: Last week, I got invited to emcee the AI Innovation Expo by Boab and moderate two-panel discussions about AI. First, there was a debate between Dr Catriona Wallace and Jeremy Howard on the topic of ‚ÄúIs the AI existential threat real?‚Äù Separate from the issues of bias that occur with machine learning algorithms, there is a belief that artificial intelligence may pose a distinct threat to the future of human life on the planet. I would totally recommend watching the full discussion here . A common theme with AI entrepreneurship is that companies should target international opportunities as opposed to just a local market like Australia. The second-panel session was aimed at getting the views of each of the esteemed speakers to not only argue that AI companies should be looking to push their products to international markets, but also provide practical tips on how to do so. Panelists: Jeremy Howard , Dr Catriona Wallace , Natalie Piucco , and Jeremy Cooper , an excellent mix of panelists who provided practical and strategic advice on how to go global with AI products. You can watch it here . Finally, a ‚ÄòShark Tank‚Äô style event whereby each company is given a short amount of time to pitch their company and receive short feedback from each of the judges. An interactive session whereby the audience can select their favorite company. Don't forget to check it out here . [Verge] DeepMind tests the limits of large AI language systems with a 280-billion-parameter model : The language model is named Gopher, parameters are a quick measure of a language‚Äôs models size and complexity, meaning that Gopher is larger than OpenAI‚Äôs GPT-3 (175 billion parameters) but not as big as some more experimental systems, like Microsoft and Nvidia‚Äôs Megatron model (530 billion parameters). [LinkedIn Post] First look at the most advanced humanoid robot from Engineered Arts Designed as a platform for AI and human-robot interaction (HRI) [Meta AI] Detecting manipulated images: The Image Similarity Challenge results and winners: Most of us edit our online photos for fun: to enhance a sunset or give a friend cartoon bunny ears. But some people manipulate pictures to spread misinformation or to evade tools designed to detect harmful content. Even after a platform removes an image for breaking its rules, automatic tools might miss modified copies reposted by others. [NewScientits] AI reads boring terms and conditions documents so you don't have to : Almost no one reads the long and complicated T&C agreements found on websites and apps, but now an AI can pick out the important bits for you. These legal documents are famously impenetrable ‚Äì a 2019 study of 500 popular websites found that 99% required a reading age beyond that of the average person in the US. [MIT] Machine-learning system flags remedies that might do more harm than good: Sepsis claims the lives of nearly 270,000 people in the U.S. each year. The unpredictable medical condition can progress rapidly, leading to a swift drop in blood pressure, tissue damage, multiple organ failure, and death. [VB] How bias creeps into the AI designed to detect toxicity: Studies show that language models amplify the biases in data on which they were trained. For instance, Codex, a code-generating model developed by OpenAI, can be prompted to write ‚Äúterrorist‚Äù when fed the word ‚ÄúIslam.‚Äù Another large language model from Cohere tends to associate men and women with stereotypically ‚Äúmale‚Äù and ‚Äúfemale‚Äù occupations, like ‚Äúmale scientist‚Äù and ‚Äúfemale housekeeper.‚Äù [Google AI] Unlocking human rights information with machine learning: Human rights defenders need information from many sources to do their work effectively. But as issues evolve and new precedents are set, finding the right information to defend a particular case can be like looking for a needle in a haystack. [Google AI] Perspectives on Issues in AI Governance : This paper can help in evolving the discussion to address pragmatic policy ideas and implementation. The ‚Äòrules of the road‚Äô for AI (be they in the form of laws or norms) will need to evolve over time to reflect thoughtful and informed consideration of economic and social priorities and attitudes, as well as keeping pace with what is possible technologically. [MIT] Tiny machine learning design alleviates a bottleneck in memory usage on internet-of-things devices TinyML offers numerous advantages over deep machine learning that happens on larger devices, like remote servers and smartphones. These include privacy since the data are not transmitted to the cloud for computing but processed on the local device; robustness, as the computing, is quick and the latency is low; and low cost, because IoT devices cost roughly $1 to $2 [Paper] WantWords: An Open-source Online Reverse Dictionary System: ( CODE ): A reverse dictionary takes descriptions of words as input and outputs words semantically matching the input descriptions. headline: Last week, I had 2 technical Googlers in my podcast separately talking about their journey, some tips, and tricks for career success. Nevin Yilmaz is a Data Scientist at Google.
post_text: Last week, I had 2 technical Googlers in my podcast separately talking about their journey, some tips, and tricks for career success. Nevin Yilmaz is a Data Scientist at Google . She has an interesting journey, studied global and international affairs at university but later found her interest in science and math. She shares about her pathway to success and some insights about standing out as a data scientist from the crowd. Check the full interview here. Marily Nika is an AR/VR Experience Product Lead at Google . She had to overcome many obstacles to start her career in tech. She talked about her story from starting Ph.D. studies in computer science to teaching at Harvard Business School and advocating for more women in tech. To know more about the role of a product manager and building a successful AI product , check the full conversation here. [Nature] AI-Based MuSIC Reveals Previously Unknown Cell Components : researchers have combined microscopy, biochemistry, and artificial intelligence techniques to advance the understanding of the cell by revealing previously unknown cell components . In doing so, they have taken what they think may turn out to be a significant leap forward in the understanding of human cells. [LinkedIn Post] NVIDIA set records across all eight popular workloads in the MLPerf training for the fastest to train at scale. [NewScientist] Humans and AI working together can reveal new areas of mathematics : AI software has collaborated with mathematicians to successfully develop a theorem about the structure of knots, but the suggestions given by the code were so unintuitive that they were initially dismissed. Only later were they discovered to offer invaluable insight. [VB] Meta launches PyTorch Live to build AI-powered mobile experiences : It is a set of tools designed to make AI-powered experiences for mobile devices easier. PyTorch Live offers a single programming language ‚Äî JavaScript ‚Äî to build apps for Android and iOS, as well as a process for preparing custom machine learning models. [Verge] AI that can play competitive POK√âMON: AI can beat a chess grandmaster. An AI can become the StarCraft esports champion. But creating an AI that could play Pok√©mon at the competitive level has been a more elusive problem. [Synced] Microsoft‚Äôs ‚ÄòFlorence‚Äô General-Purpose Foundation Model Achieves SOTA Results on Dozens of CV Benchmarks: Task-specific models dominate today‚Äôs AI landscape, but a truly intelligent AI would be able to solve diverse real-world problems with minimal human involvement by learning joint, fundamental representations that support a broad range of downstream tasks. It‚Äôs trained on unparallel data, which means that it is not necessary to train on datasets where each identity has corresponding facial expressions.
